title: Former School-Turned-Family-Home Asks £1.25 Million
text:
An almost 140-year-old former school house in an English village in Cheshire that has been converted into a single-family home hit the market last week for £1.25 million (US$1.55 million).



Dubbed, fittingly, Old School House, the gothic revival-style building was built in 1872 and was used as the primary school—serving children aged 5 to 11—for the village of Spurstow until 1983, when it was converted into a residence, according to the listing with estate agency Savills.



More: London’s Kensington Palace Gardens Ranks as Most Expensive Street in Britain

The conversion was undertaken by a previous owner, said Charlie Kannreuther, head of the North West and West Midlands at Savills.



“Whoever did the original [conversion] did a great job of not stripping out that character,” Mr. Kannreuther said.



In what was once the school hall, a room that now serves as the drawing room and the focal point of the house, there’s original parquet flooring, mullioned windows and an ornamental fireplace.



The home has two staircases leading to the second floor. The main staircase leads from the drawing room up to a galleried landing with exposed trusses and beams currently fitted with theater seating and used as a cinema room. Two of the home’s four bedrooms are reached via the landing.



A second staircase in the study—formerly the head teacher's office—leads up to the other two bedrooms.

The house has recently undergone a comprehensive modernization by the current owners, according to the listing. Mansion Global could not determine the identity of the owners.



“One of the key things they've done is invest in the garden,” Mr. Kannreuther said. “The gardens are magical. [They’re] divided into various areas with hedging and a pond, and there’s a really smart summer house structure at the end of the garden.”



Also in the garden are a range of brick outbuildings, including the former school bathroom block with a store room, utility room and separate log store. There is also a former air raid shelter, now used for storage space.
